captions.text:
So I'm sitting in the back of
a Mercedes Viano at the

moment, which must be
the fastest van I've
ever traveled in.

As you can see, I'm looking at
the footage from driving the

new SL 63 today out on the
hills above St. Tropez.
Pretty special car.

I'm afraid it's a
home production.

As you can see, there's
no one with me.

It's not just the fact that I've
got terrible body odor.

Neil's back in the UK, working
hard on another project that

you're going to be enjoying
very soon.

So please enjoy my
SL 63 AMG video.
[ENGINE REVVING]

So the new SL 63 is the
ultimate go-anywhere,

roof-up-or-roof-down
sports car.

In fact, I think it's hard to
think of a car that has to

cover more bases in
its intended role.

To me, this car is almost
schizophrenic in
what it has to do.

Because it has to be comfortable
for an old man.

It has to be sporting
for a younger chap.

It has to be loud
and exciting.

But it has to be quiet
and cosseting.

I think the phrase I'm looking
for is bipolar.

We've got the roof up, but the
weather is quite nice.

So in a minute, I think I might
just pop the roof down.

And then we'll see what it's
like to cruise in the SL 63.

So if we start out at a cruise,
then we'll climb out
of St. Tropez.

And we might as well just create
a single journey in

which we explore all of this
car's supposed talents.

So what's it like to cruise
around St. Tropez
in the new SL 63?
It's very good, actually.

You really notice how much
more stiffness this
structure has got.

Because every time an individual
wheel drops into a

little pothole or a little road
crevasse, the structure

of the car doesn't
creak at all.

It just takes that little
hit and moves on again.

It doesn't even worry
about it.
Steering is very light.

What I'm saying is this car
feels, at low speed, like an

SL 500 with slightly
firmer springs.

The throttle response isn't
too aggressive.
The steering's a bit heavier.
But it's still very light.

Electromechanical-- we'll
come to that later on.
Tuned by AMG.

And of course, being France, I'm
listening to a two-stroke
motorcycle in front of me.

Now, while we're traveling
slowly and enjoying what is a

remarkably composed, comfortable
car at low speed,
let's talk about the numbers.

The first thing is this car
is much lighter than its

predecessor, so that even though
the outgoing car had

525 horsepower, it actually
weighed thick end of 2 tons,

about 1970 kilograms, without
any extras on it.

This car is 125 kilograms
lighter.

And yet, even at standard,
it's got 537 horsepower.

That 537 horsepower is matched
by 590 foot-pounds of torque.

But this car has the
performance pack.
And the numbers go up again.

With the performance pack, you
get 564 horsepower and-- this

is the silly bit, the
really silly bit--
663 foot-pounds of torque.

I mean, it's absolutely
bonkers.
The change is all down to
calibration and boost pressure.

It's 1.0 bar in the normal car
and about 1.3 in this car.

I asked them how far they'd gone
with it to see what they

could break on the engine and
they were a bit noncommittal.

But there were lots of Germans
grinning and sniggering about
how far they'd got.

And when I said 750
horsepower, they
didn't bat an eyelid.

They did say, though, that if
you push, and push, and push

with boost pressure and more
performance and more power,

the thing that goes is that the
crankcase just goes kaboom

in a kind of nuclear
explosion.

So now we've left
St. Tropez town.

We're up and moving a
bit quicker, about
55, 60 miles an hour.

And we can be objective about
the car as a convertible GT
going faster.

Again, the structure feels
very, very strong.

So each wheel is moving
independently.
The ride is pretty good.

I can't tell much more about
the ride because
it's such a flat road.

So maybe later on, we can tell
more about the ride.

But the car doesn't feel
too busy to me at all.
It feels very composed.

In terms of buffeting,
there is a bit.

But we can solve that slightly
by moving the old wind
deflector up.

So when I press that, that
raises the thingy behind me.

You can just see it
going up in the
corner of the shot there.

And now suddenly, from behind
our heads, there's very little
air coming into the cabin.

Put my foot down, and now, this
is when the SL does stuff
that not many cars can do.

The really clever bit about
this car happens when you
decide to go a bit quicker.

Let me change the gearbox into
manual, maybe put the ESP into

sport mode, start changing
gear yourself.

And then, honestly,
it is bipolar.
There's no other word for it.
[TIRES SCREECHING]

It's just extraordinary,
absolutely extraordinary.

Turn everything off, and yeah,
it becomes an animal.
[TIRES SCREECHING]

I stand by what I said before
about this MCT gearbox.

I prefer it to a
double-clutch.

I think in its combined roles
of comfort, smoothness, and

then just being a bit stupid
when you want to, it's great.
It's absolutely superb.
Yeah, I like this car.
I really like this car.

The SL 63 is a far, far better
car than the one it replaces.

The electric power steering is
much more accurate than the
new SL 500s.

And it's at its best
in sport mode.
But it has some extra weight.

But what really shines through
in this car is the sheer depth

of engineering and the
attention to detail.

The seats are a cross
between an armchair
and a racing bucket.

The optional B&O Hi-Fi
gets those funky
tweeters from the SLS.

But the best bits are
perhaps the wipers.

Roof down, they only squirt
through these tiny, little

holes in the blades on the
downstroke to keep those wigs
nice and dry.

You see, the SL 63 has pretty
much everything.

I just wish it looked
a little bit better.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: 2012 Mercedes SL63 AMG Bi-Turbo review: Gentleman, Thug - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
Okay, I think he used bipolar as a play off of biturbo. But bipolar means 
massive ups and assize downs. Schizophrenic involves the presence of 
multiple personalities. So, honestly, I think he actually MEANT 
schizophrenic from felt the need to use bipolar as a play off of biturbo. 
His point was this car has multiple personas. Mild car about town. Comfy, 
taught GT and MANIC, BALLS OUT BEAST. That, to me, would equate to three 
personalities, or schizophrenia. I don't challenge me on this, please

comments.author: joinbd

comments.text:
Bi-Turbo used to mean that there was a small turbo and a large turbo (for 
instant response and top end), while twin turbo just meant two equally 
sized turbos. Lately though "bi-turbo" has been the go to phrase for what 
manufacturers call cars with twin turbos. Sounds fancier I guess.
comments.author: iXetsuei

comments.text: nothing, just another way of saying twin turbo

comments.text:
bi turbo is another term for sequential turbo, one smaller one for low rpm 
and a larger one for high rpm, in an effort to reduce lag, and twin turbo 
means 2 turbos the same size
